details.history: Started in 1961 when Mario Andreoli lit three lights on a cross to honor a promise to his dying father. Over 60 years, he expanded it into a masterpiece using his railway worker skills and recycled materials including iron, windows, old signs, and tanks.

organizer.name: Associazione Presepe di Manarola Mario Andreoli

details.significance: World's largest lighted nativity scene, symbol of dedication, community, and sustainable art. Represents the dialogue between human creativity and the wine landscape.
details.description_long: Created by retired railway worker Mario Andreoli starting in 1961, this extraordinary nativity scene cascades down the hillside above Manarola. With over 300 life-sized figures made entirely from recycled materials and illuminated by more than 17,000 lights powered by renewable energy, it entered the Guinness World Records in 2007. The installation transforms the terraced vineyards into a stunning work of environmental art, blending faith, creativity, and sustainability. Andreoli dedicated his life to this project until his passing in 2022, and it continues through the Associazione Presepe di Manarola.
details.description_short: The world's largest illuminated nativity scene featuring over 300 figures and 17,000 lights spread across terraced hillside, created from recycled materials.

schedule_of_activities.activity: Opening of Oratory with photography exhibitions
CAI torchlight procession and authorities' greetings
Nativity scene lighting and fireworks (December 8 only)

location.venue_name: Collina delle Tre Croci (Hill of Three Crosses)
location.meeting_point: Main square Manarola or Via Beccara trail for best views

schedule.schedule_notes: Lit nightly from approximately 5:00 PM to 10:00 PM (until midnight on Sundays). Opening ceremony with fireworks on December 8.
schedule.recurrence_pattern: Daily from December 8 to end of January/early February

cons: Requires climbing steps for best view

attendance.peak_hours: Opening night December 8 and weekend evenings
attendance.best_arrival_time: Arrive before 17:00 to secure good viewing spot, especially on opening night

parking.notes: No parking in Manarola. Use La Spezia parking and take train.

practical_info.what_to_wear: Warm winter clothing, sturdy shoes for uneven terrain and steps

accessibility.accessibility_notes: Best viewing requires climbing 170-320 steps on Via Beccara trail. Can be viewed from main square but with limited view.

public_transport.train_service: Manarola station on Cinque Terre line, frequent service

tickets_pricing.price_notes: Completely free to view from public viewing areas

weather_contingency.rain_policy: Operates in most weather, but trail may be dangerous when wet

avoid: Opening night if you dislike crowds
Rainy evenings when trail is slippery
combine_with: Visit during day to see figures up close
insider_tips: Climb to highest viewing area (320 steps) on Via Beccara for best panoramic view
Bring flashlight - trail has no lighting at night
Visit on December 8 for opening ceremony and fireworks
Best photos from Via Beccara viewpoints, not main square
Go on weeknight to avoid weekend crowds
best_viewing_spots: Via Beccara trail - three viewing areas at 170, 250, and 320 steps
